english: to practice; to train; to refine; to temper

etymology.description: semantic: 糸 ‘silk’ + phonetic: 柬; simplified from 練 (柬 → 𫠣).
etymology.interpretation: Silk signals an original sense related to working or refining silk threads, while 柬 supplies the sound. The idea of refining silk extended metaphorically to refining skills, yielding meanings like practice, train, and temper.
etymology.simplification: Stroke reduction: 糸 was simplified to 纟 and the phonetic 柬 was replaced by 𫠣, preserving the pronunciation while easing writing.

examples.chinese: 我每天练钢琴(我每天練鋼琴)。
examples.english: I practice the piano every day.

examples.chinese: 教练让我们反复练动作(教練讓我們反覆練動作)。
examples.pinyin: Jiàoliàn ràng wǒmen fǎnfù liàn dòngzuò.
examples.english: The coach had us repeat the moves for practice.

examples.chinese: 经过多年打磨，他的技艺越练越精(經過多年打磨，他的技藝越練越精)。
examples.pinyin: Jīngguò duō nián dǎmó, tā de jìyì yuè liàn yuè jīng.
examples.english: After years of honing, his skills became ever more polished.
